  • Consulting before building the wrong thing

     Feb 1, 2017

    This past month I mentioned that I had acquired a new client that is looking to build a livestreaming video platform for webroadcasts and webinars.

    We've spent the past few weeks outlining a scope of work and digging into the details to develop a full understanding of the company vision as well as what's required to get to an MVP.

    After multiple sessions of ironing out the specifics, it became apparent that the best path to success wasn't to just start building an inflexible demo, but to do more research to find a scaleable solution.

    In this case, we found that instead of using a two solutions tied together with hard code, that an end-to-end technology is a better solution that reduces complexity and offers additional benefits in the form of analytics and integrations.

    It's great to have the chance to work directly with clients in my pursuit to become a better Product Manager. I've learned that it is extremely important to fully comprehend a client's vision and goals before moving into the design/build process. It saved me weeks of time and prevented them from wasting money on a semi-useful product that wouldn't scale.

  • Checking off tickets at WeWork

     Jan 31, 2017

    I took a trip downtown to tour two different WeWork offices today. The first one was near the White House and the other was in Dupont Circle.

    It was nice to work in a new environment and I was able to check off all but one of my tickets on the sprint board. Another plus was being able to get feedback from random people in the coworking space.

    I'm not sure if it makes sense for me to commit to the coworking space at this point, but I'm going to sleep on it.

  • One week sprints for a better workflow

     Jan 30, 2017

    The needs of each team change over time and as a product manager it's my job to make decisions to improve the effectiveness of the team's workflow.

    With all of our team members having full time commitments (jobs, school, clients), our building process with Stash has been divided and inconsistent. This has led to a gap between design and development where neither side is aware of what the other is working on. We have a sprint board for development, but the design work hasn't been tracked.

    Our team needs a better way to keep track of all of our work in one place so we can set goals together, log our work, and hold each other accountable. The solution is to include design objectives to our sprint board and shorten the sprints to one week.

    I'm excited to see how this improves our workflow. Grind time.

  • Museum view in React

     Jan 27, 2017

    My web work day got shortened because I went to work as a photographer tonight in DC.

    One of the things I was learning about before I left was how to create a museum view for Stash's cards. The main problem with the current version is that items are added in columns instead of in rows. The only way to get the items to position themselves in rows is to use a technique called Masonry.

    There are plugins that enable this dynamic positioning in React that I will need to use to create this effect. That'll have to wait a couple days though because I'm headed to NYC with Kristina tomorrow morning 🗽!

  • Committed to uncovering the truth

     Jan 25, 2017

    The truth is out there, but recently people with power have been using their influence to publicly dispute facts and create obstacles to make it difficult for citizens to access important information.

    Osebo and I decided that we needed to do our part in helping people access fact based information on environmental, social, economic, and educational issues.

    We chose the name "Hidden Info" because we're committed to uncovering the truth. We'll strive to be unbiased and our writing will require a great deal of research and fact checking to ensure we put out is 100% truthful. We will be providing sources for our findings.

    Today we whipped up a basic prototype just to get a sense for what we need to include in the experience.

  • California job apps and Stashing with Diego

     Jan 24, 2017

    I applied to two PM jobs in San Jose that look promising. I've always loved the valley and if I do land a job out there, it would be almost impossible to decline.

    After work hours, I attended a hacker meetup with Diego.

    We spent time working on the error messages for user registration.

    Osebo also wanted to see what it would look like if we used a museum style view for Stash's cards, so I built a quick prototype.

    The design is nice, but items that only have a favicon or no image at all create gaps in the layout. Another concern is that it only adds content to the left column rather than adding items across horizontally in rows. That may cause confusion for the user in regards to which items were most recently saved.

    I don't think we're quite ready to implement something like the museum view until we can grab screenshots of webpages that don't have meta images. More on this in the future.

  • React, Redux and progress with Stash

     Jan 19, 2017

    Today, Diego and I spent some quality time together working on Stash. We're working on creating left and right arrows for moving between items within the overlay.

    It required quite of bit of refactoring and requires manipulating the global state with Redux.

    I'm happy that Diego has been taking the time to walk me through the relationships between the actions, dispatches, reducers and states.

    Learning this component based framework is hard work, but I know it will pay off. Excited to share the experience with you soon.

     Jan 11, 2017

    Being a product manager is my true role. I love driving products from concept to reality by connecting business, development, and design.

    But defining my role as a product manager can be difficult at times because every circumstance need something different. I am constantly having to adapt to the needs of my product, market, and teammates while balancing both budget and time.

    So I spent some time today researching more about how other people define the role of a product manager and the techniques they use to optimize their effectiveness.

    I found a lot of stuff, but one thing that I really like is this graphic.

    It does a very good job of breaking down the areas a PM is involved with and the responsibilities within each area of focus.

    I'm going to continue to soak up more knowledge and use the insights to start applying for roles as a PM.

  • Learning Gulp and first development for my portfolio

     Jan 10, 2017

    Gulp is a javascript task runner that helps automate tasks like bundling code and minifying images/gifs etc.

    Because my personal site will have a lot of heavy imagery, I decided to use gulp to build my personal site so that it's fast and snappy.

    I like it's plugin/modular infrastructure and the fact that it uses sass by default.

    On another note, the site design continues to change as I show people and get feedback. I'm think I'm goint to adjust my user flow so that there are individual pages for each project.

    It's cool to see how it changes day over day.

  • Conducting problem interviews for Stash

     Jan 8, 2017

    Products need to solve problems. Whether it's telling you the time or autonomously driving you to work, products are created to solve a human problem.

    Today, Osebo and I interviewed a bio-med engineering masters student named Mishi.

    She was super nice and gave us a lot of great insight into her daily experience of discovering and saving online. Her go-to service is/was Tumblr, but it's gotten really cluttered and difficult for her to easily revisit her favorite content.

    The conversation was extremely helpful in identifying where her painpoints lie and how we can shape Stash's experience to solve her problems.

    Talking with Mishi also gave us a better understanding of who our target audience is. I'm not going to draw any conclusions yet, but we're excited to conduct more interviews to see if there are any consistent patterns.

  • Collecting facts on climate change for an interactive infographic

     Jan 7, 2017

    One topic that has captured my attention recently is global warming. There is so much controversy surrounding the issue, but there is no denying that human carbon emissions are causing alarming outcomes.

    Even though climate change has been gaining media coverage, people still seem to be unaware of the long term consequences from our current carbon output or don't care enough to make changes in their daily lives.

    I want to do my part to help inform others about the realities of global warming by creating a interactive inforgraphic about climate change.

    I've started collecting research and here are some of the mind-boggling facts that I found:

    • Every single day, 70 million tons of carbon dioxide are released into the earth’s atmosphere. That’s 1.4 billion pounds – yesterday, today, tomorrow... [1]
    • Since temperature record-keeping began in 1880, the 10 warmest years on record have been in the past 12 years. [2]
    • 20 million tons of ice are lost per day from just one glacier in Greenland. This amount of daily ice lost is equal to the amount of water that New York City uses in an entire year. [3]
    • Over a hundred million people will be displaced by just a 1-yard rise in sea levels. Many scientists predict that the oceans will rise at least this much by 2100. [4]

    I don't want my children and grandchildren to never experience snow, or to have to wear medicical masks just to prevent them from inhaling smog. We only have one Earth, lets make changes to keep it habitable for future generations.

  • Researching the psychology of collecting

     Jan 2, 2017

    While working with Osebo on Stash today, we decided to dig into the true problem that we're attempting to solve with Stash. It started with a question. Why do people collect things?

    "Collecting is a basic human instinct; a survival advantage amplified by eons of natural selection. Those of our ancient ancestors who managed to accumulate scarce objects may have been more prone to survive long enough to bear offspring." (source)

    If you think about it, everyone collects something. Baseball cards, money, pictures, letters from loved ones, sneakers... something. Our motivations to collect stem from a few common reasons including:

    • Knowledge and learning
    • Relaxation and stress reduction
    • Personal pleasure
    • Social interaction with fellow collectors and others
    • Competitive challenge
    • Recognition by fellow collectors and perhaps even non-collectors
    • The desire to control, possess and bring order to part of the world
    • Nostalgia and/or a connection to history
    • Accumulation and diversification of wealth

    So how does this apply to Stash? We feel like collecting content on the web is difficult, unappealing, and hidden from others who can find value in it.

    Right now, to collect webpages, images, videos, etc., people either: share links on chat platforms where they get lost in conversation, create bookmark folders that often get forgotten/cluttered, or build websites for their collection, which take a significant amount of time and effort to create/maintain.

    Our goal is to make it easier for people to create, share, and discover collections of their favorite media.
